texts.en: Urtnasan O. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, western of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Urtnasan and his wife operate a food trading business out of a store in their town. He began his business on the advice of his wife in 1991. He purchased a small store with 2,500,000 MNT where they sell consumer food. His daily profit ranges between 80,000 to 100,000 MNT. Not only has his business grown in profits, he plans to expand the store as a supermarket and increase the amount and types of products he sells. The family purchased a small car with their business profit and now their working capital and supplement has reached 1,800,000 MNT. Urtnasan is requesting a 3,300,000 MNT loan in order to enlarge his business.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: Lang T. N. was born in 1962. She lives in Xuan Non village. She has two children: a daughter and a son. Her husband is a contractor. She grows rice and raises chicken.  She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2003 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed

loans.name: Chieu

texts.en: Chieu T. N. was born in 1963. She has two sons. She is a farmer. She not only grows rice, but also raises pigs. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2003 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed the pigs and poultry.

loans.use: to breed pigs and poultry

loans.name: Yanjindulam

texts.en: Yanjindulam G. lives with her husband and her family in a ger, a traditional housing tent in Uvs province, in the western part of Mongolia. Her husband works seasonally in a construction company as a decorator with a salary of 250,000 MNT while Yanjindulam operates a food retail business in their town. She had worked in her town as a nurse for more than 30 years and had been retired in 2009. Her current working capital exceeds 2,000,000 MNT and her daily revenue is between 80,000 and 90,000 MNT. She is planning to expand her small stall and says, “I am trying to afford my youngest son's tuition fees and planning to enlarge my small stall as a supermarket”.  Yanjindulam is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of food products at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Porn

texts.en:
Mrs. Porn O. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them for breeding and for slaughter. In addition, she distills white wine to sell and uses leftovers from the distilling process to feed the pigs. Porn O. has three kids who attend the local public school. Her husband is a farmer and sells firewood. 


Presently, Porn O.’s husband faces difficulties delivering chop-wood from the forest in that he always hires an animal when he needs transportation. To reduce this cost, Porn O. would like to buy a buffalo. This will alleviate the transportation problem in her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo.

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeun C. (pictured in her grocery store), 62 years old, is a widow with one son and four daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home and the other three work in a factory. They live in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Yoeun has been selling groceries for 10 years. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market for resale at her home. She hopes to purchase more grocery items to better respond to her customer’s needs, so she is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to use for that purpose.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun U. (shown in the picture), and her husband, Mr. Chanthol Thorn, have been married for almost two years and just have a young daughter. The family lives in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh. 

Chanthoeun sells soup and pickled fruits at her home. She used to be a hairdresser as well. Her husband has been a motorbike repairer for more than five years. He runs the business at his own shop next to his house. 

Chanthoeun is asking for a loan in the amount of US $600 to pay for school fees for her brother who is in his third year of banking. She also will use a part of the loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To pay for school fees for her brother

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Mrs. Nov C. is a widowed woman and the mother of six children, one of whom is now married and lives independently, while the remaining five are single and employed. To pursue a daily income, Nov C. makes and sells some food and cakes in her store next to her house. 

Nov C. has another skill in raising pigs and she wants to use this knowledge to earn extra income, but she doesn’t have capital. Thus, she has applied for a loan in order to purchase piglets to breed.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to breed.

loans.name: Kannha

texts.en:
Mrs. Kannha S. (pictured with her husband) and her husband, Mr. Sochea Phan, live in a small village off of National Road Two, about 17 kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2001 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them attend school and another one is still young and stays at home.

Kannha is a rice farmer. In the past, she used to sell vegetables. Her husband has full time employment in Phnom Penh. She does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm. Hence she is requesting a loan of US $600 to help increase her capital.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora L. is from the town of Aurora. She is 40 years old. Flora is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Flora owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Flora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer, such as manure, and other farm inputs. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Flora from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie O. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 36 years old. Tessie is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business providing motorcycle services to local community members. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Tessie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gantugs

texts.en: Gantugs J. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Gantugs and his wife operate an agriculture business in their town. They began their business early in 2010 and since then, they have been able to rent a plot of land for two years where they operate agriculture with some friends as a group. They have begun this business based on the experience of working on World Vision Organization's training, which enabled them to plant vegetables and other plants grown for food. Gantugs wants to keep expanding the amounts and types of vegetables under the supervision of an experienced trainer in the group. Gantugs is a neat, hardworking and straight person. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of fertilizer and composting soil, watering equipment and seed for his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, compost, seeds and equipment

loans.name: Seam

texts.en:
Mrs. Seam D. (pictured above), age 50, and her husband, Mr. Kem Sam, age 53, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have nine children: seven sons and two daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, one is a construction worker, three are in school and one assists his parents in the business. 

Seam and her husband have been raising pigs and producing rice wine since 1981. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $600 to purchase additional piglets to raise. She will use part of her loan to buy a motorbike to carry rice wine to sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie O. is from the village of  Pigsag an Cagayan de Oro City. He is 34 years old. Ronie is married and has 2 infants. Ronie owns & operates a  sari-sari (variety) retail shop where he sells food & daily use products. Ronie has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ronie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Ronie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ronie is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Ronie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding his business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Samphois

texts.en:
Mrs. Samphois S. is 34 years old and her husband, Mr. Sophay Phat, is 41 years old. They are pictured together. They have been married since 1992 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their sons is a security guard; three of their children attend school and the other one stays at home. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.   

Samphois has been a silk weaver for ten years: a skill she learnt from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then sells them in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been security guard for a year. 


Samphois wants to start a new business raising pigs. She hopes she will be able to get extra income from selling pigs when they grow big enough. Hence she is asking for a loan of $500 to build a pigpen and to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To build a pigpen and to buy piglets

loans.name: Kaen

texts.en:
Mr. Kaen A. was born in 1962 and is a married man. (His wife appears in the photo.) He currently lives in a commune of Kompong Tom Province. He was married here and has four children, all of whom are students in the local public school. 

In 2005, Kaen A. became a professional teacher in the Christ school and also teaches some students who come to study at his home. He is currently earning an average of $2.80 per day, while his wife works as a rattan cupboard maker. 

Kaen A. lacks a table for his students to store their books but he has no money to buy it yet. Therefore, Kaen A. has requested a loan to be used to buy tables.

loans.use: To buy tables for his students

loans.name: Sam-Onn

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-onn S. is 30 years old and is single. He lives with his parents, brothers and sisters in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. He is a policeman. 

One of Sam-onn’s brothers has full-time employment but he does not have his own transportation to get work and spends a lot of money on traveling costs. S., Sam-onn is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for his brother to drive to work.  

Photo: Mr. Sam-onn S..

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his brother to drive to work.

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren D. is 35 years old and lives with her two children in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a house which is owned by her mother. The family's living conditions are good and she is able to operate a business trading goods at a local market.  


Myagmarsuren sells a variety of clothes and garments. She purchases most of her goods from Ereen, a city on the Chinese border, once or twice a month, depending on sales. She transports them back to the market to sell. Myagmarsuren started her business in 1997 and quickly established herself in the local business community. She hopes to soon expand her business and increase her earnings. 


Myagmarsuren is a gentle, hardworking and neat woman. She says, “I am trying my best to have my own house, enlarge my business in the future. I wish I would have a small clothes store in my town.” 


 She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes and warm garments to sell and to decorate and repair the house in which she is currently living.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Voeung

texts.en:
Voeung S., 38, is a single man living with his older mother in a wooden house located in a commune of Kompong Tom Province. His mother is a widowed woman who appears in the photo. She earns a living by selling various cakes and desserts to her neighbors. 

Voeung S. has learned a skill of turning gold block into jewelry. He is called a goldsmith, and he currently uses his knowledge to generate a daily income. Voeung S. always faces difficulty traveling to his workplace or anywhere else, because he has no vehicle for his riding needs. Thus, he would like to ask for a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL, to be used to buy a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar D. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and child in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, in Uvs province of western Mongolia. His wife works as cleaner in a local restaurant while his child stays at home. 


Otgonbayar operates a raw material business in his town. He started his business with the help of his older brother. Otgonbayar operates his business seasonally. He purchases skins and wool from herders and sells them for a profit at the central market. His daily profit ranges from 500 to 1000 MNT. 


Otgonbayar is an open-minded and easy going person. He is requesting a 390,000MNT loan to purchase more livestock skins at wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Choun

texts.en:
Mrs. Choun P. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Touch Say, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1969 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home and the other one attends school. Her husband is a farmer. 

Choun has been selling potatoes for 20 years. She buys potatoes from farmers in her village and sells to a middleman who comes to buy them at her home. She also assists her husband in his farming business.

Choun does not have enough capital to purchase potatoes under contract before harvest season comes, so she is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,000 to help her capital.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes under contract for resale.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en: Dina D. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 41 years old, married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Dina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Dina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2008, Dina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Dina is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Dina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Mrs. Chin R., aged 27, owns and operates a handicraft business with the main activity being the sale of rattan cupboards. She sells rattan that her husband weaves or she orders from other weavers who live in the village. She uses her horse cart for transportation and it takes a week to sell all her rattan.

Mrs. Chin R. has been facing difficulties transporting her rattan because her horse cart is slow and this affects her ability to satisfy the needs of her customers. Because of this problem, she decided to request a loan to purchase a dragging machine to which she will attach her existing cart, so she can transport her product more quickly. She is a good mother to her two school-aged children. She was busy when the photo was taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a dragging machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny C. is 50 years old and her husband, Mr. Thorn Sum, is 52 years old.  They live in a small village across the Mekong River approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1977 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Four of them are married and live in separate homes, one is in school and another one assists his parents in the business.  

Vanny and her husband are farmers. They grow sugar cane on their farmland in the village. The couple does not have enough capital to use on their sugar cane farm, so Vanny is asking for a loan of $500 to help her capital.

Vanny will use her loan to pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer to maintain her farm. 

In the photo, Mrs. Vanny C. was at home and not at her sugar cane farm.

loans.use: To use for growing sugar cane.

loans.name: Soninbayar

texts.en:
Soninbayar L. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife operates a food and consumer goods small-business in Uyanga sub-province of Uvurhangai while Soninbayar operates public transport between Uyanga sub-province and Arvaiheer, the center of Uvurhangai province.

Soninbayar began his business in 2003 and has gained a lot of experience since then. Because of the trip and routine, his car is in constant need of upkeep and repair. He is planning on purchasing a new car when he can afford it but, for now, he is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a car for his business in order to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To purchase a taxi for his business

loans.name: Sreypov

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov V., age 22, and her husband, Mr. Sokhim Pan, age 27, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have been married for one-and-a-half years and just have a young son. Besides her son, Sreypov also has her mother living with her. 

Sreypov has been a garment factory worker for one year and her husband has been a cell phone vendor for one year. He buys phones in Phnom Penh to resell at his home. He also supplements his existing business by selling MP3 and MP4 players and by repairing phones and installing cell phone applications.

Sreypov is applying for her first loan of $600 to help finance her husband to purchase additional cell phones for resale.

loans.use: To help finance her husband to purchase additional cell phones for resale

loans.name: Merencia

texts.en: Merencia M. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 58 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Merencia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling bananas, coconuts and cassava in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Merencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merencia is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Or

texts.en: Mrs. Or S. is 48 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She raises rice crops and pigs, which she can raise twice a year. She is widowed and the mother of six children; two are married and live away from the family home, and four are single and go to school or work. Mrs. Or S. is a hard-working woman who never wastes time in order to earn money to ensure that her family has a comfortable standard of living. The coming dry season is good for growing crops but she has no money to buy supplies to use on her field so she has applied for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To buy supplies to use on her field

loans.name: Ulziihuu

texts.en:
Ulziihuu C. is 51 years old and lives with her two daughters in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Ulziihuu operates a traditional clothing business in her town and has taught her daughter tailoring. She began her business in 1995 with the help of some friends in a small tailoring center with the rent of 35,000 MNT per month. Her dream is to keep growing her business and to eventually be able to afford to rent her own tailoring center with her daughter.

Ulziihuu is a hardworking and optimistic woman who is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase necessary fabrics and finishing materials for her clothes and costumes.

loans.use: To purchase necessary fabrics and finishing materials

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Chorn Y., 54 years old, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items including cooking ingredients, sweets and soft drinks. She sells her inventory to people who pass by and also to her neighbors. She has been running a grocery store for a long time and earns an average of over $2.50 a day. She is a widow woman blessed with two children, both of whom are now married and live at home. Chorn Y. is taking out her loan to increase her inventory and to buy piece of land to improve the conditions surrounding her house.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to buy piece of land

loans.name: Bibigul

texts.ru: Махмадиева Бибигул проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 51 год. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Муж вместе с детьми работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Они занимаются растениеводством. Сама Бибигул имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота. Она хочет увеличить количество скот.
texts.en:
Bibigul M. lives in the Yavan region. She is 51 years old; she married and has 5 children. Her husband and children work at a farm, they raise crops. Bibgul has a secondary education. For over 5 years she has been working in animal husbandry, breeding livestock at home. She is requesting the loan to purchase cattle, she would like to increase the number of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase cattle

loans.name: Crisanta

texts.en: Crisanta P. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 59 years old, is widowed, and has nine adult children. Crisanta owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Crisanta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Crisanta is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic P. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 30 years old. Marivic is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marivic from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Shazia lives with her husband and family in the mid-sized city of Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband, a loader by profession, has been working in a brick furnace for over ten years, using his donkey cart to deliver the bricks to the designated recipients.

Shazia, a mother of nine, takes care of her family and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife. She has repaid her first loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is now applying for a new loan so her husband can replace his old and damaged cart. A new cart will enable him to carry a greater load and thus earn more income.

loans.use: Purchase a new donkey cart for loading

loans.name: Amila

texts.en:
Amila L., from the town of Aurora, is 28 years old, married and has a five-year-old and a six-month-old child. To make a living, Amila owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been involved in farming for more than a few years now.

Amila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new one for 8000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Amita's third loan from CEVI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel D. is from the town of Aurora. She is 34 years old. Maribel is married and has three school-age children. She dreams for her children to someday finish college and find suitable jobs for themselves in the future. 

To make a living, Maribel owns a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops, which mainly consists of planting and harvesting rice for sale.

In 2009, Maribel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maribel from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house and supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena T., 34, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Erwin T., a vendor, they are blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She manages her own food stall where she sells rice porridge, which is a very popular snack here in the Philippines.

Rowena has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her food business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 10,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by paying for raw ingredients needed to continue the production of her rice porridge.

Rowena dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide well for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed to continue the production of her rice porridge

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine J., 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Johnimar J., a goldsmith, they are blessed in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own gold jewelry business while also doing direct selling and retailing of electronic cellular phone load.

Josephine has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 31,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy more products to be incorporated into her current inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more products to add to her inventory

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila N. is from the town of Aurora. She is 60 years old. Leonila is married and has seven adult children. She is involved in farming and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than twenty years. Aside from farming, she also manages a sari-sari (convenience) store located at her house. She sells vinegar, sugar and other basic needs products that most people in her community look for.

Leonila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonila has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leonila from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for her crops

loans.name: Macarlina

texts.en:
Macarlina G. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Macarlina is married and has four school-age children. 

To make a living, Macarlina owns a specialized retail store which primarily sells seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Macarlina has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Macarlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Macarlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Macarlina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Macarlina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Balbina

texts.en:
Balbina P., 60, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her five children can have a better life.  She has been managing her own eatery for the past few years.

Balbina has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her eatery.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 14,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy raw ingredients needed to continue the operation of her eatery.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful so that she can finally have financial stability and have a credit-free business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed to continue the operation of her eatery

loans.name: Vigae Group

texts.en:
Hassan M., 41, is married with two children, ages 15 and 5 years old.  He has owned a Genge business (grocery stall which sells Kiwahili fruits and vegetables) for 10 years.  He works from 6 am to 11pm daily and he is able to make a monthly profit of about $201.

This will be Hassan’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He wants to get a loan to increase his Genge stock. EventuA. he hopes to buy a car, which will help him move his stock more easily, and also be useful for the family.

Hassan will share this loan with his loan group Vigae, which totals 17 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Hassan is seated on the left in the first row.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat H. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Leang Lonh, live in a small village off of National Road Two about seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have three sons and three daughters. Two of them are married and live outside of the family home. Two are garment factory workers, one attends school and another one stays at home. 

Yat and her husband are farmers. They grow cucumbers, squash and other crops on their farmland in the village. Besides farming, they are also fishermen. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $600 to purchase a boat and fishing material for her fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and fishing material for her fishing business.

loans.name: Regie

texts.en:
Regie M. is a married woman who lives in Banaba, Kalumbuyan, Bawayan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures. She sells RTWs (ready-to-wear clothing) and she also buys and sells jewelry. Her husband, Ramil M., who is 42 years old, works as a driver to earn a living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have seven children between the ages of 4 months and 20 years.
 
Regie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Regie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $112 - raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th cycle loan, she is again borrowing 19,000 PHP which she intends to use as additional capital for her businesses so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs and pay for her children's education. Regie M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice, a married woman with a one-year-old child, has been operating her fuel gas business for two years with the help of her husband. She sells in a shop and as retail to restaurant operators, hotel businesses, and villagers. Alice decided to join Yehu to acquire a loan to enable her to expand the business. With a loan of 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase stock for a new branch in town, hoping to have five branches in the future. The biggest challenge she faces in her business is theft.

Alice rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To acquire more fuel to stock a new branch

loans.name: Simorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Simorn U., 57 (pictured here), is a widow with one daughter who is in grade 12. She lives along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Simorn has been selling fish for ten years, purchasing them from fisherman in the village and transporting them to sell at Prek Phnao market. She is also a rice farmer.

Simorn is applying for her first loan, in the amount of $400, to purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita M., a 57-year old married woman who lives in Talusan, Brgy. Bulanon, Sagay City, earns a living by operating her own fishing business. Rosita’s husband, Carlo, is a fisherman, and they have eight children who are school-age and adult-age, including a daughter working abroad. They own two vehicles which their two sons take care of for their business, and they also have a sugarcane farm.

Rosita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1990 to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the assistance of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by starting a fishing business, now earning an average monthly income of Php10,000. A member in good standing, Rosita's previous loan of Php29,500 was used to fund operations for her fishing business and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now requesting her 16th loan in the amount of Php29,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital, Rosita is working hard to achieve her dreams for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Maria Natividad

texts.en:
Maria Natividad R., a married woman who lives in Sito Canalum, Nangka, Bawayan City, Negros Oriental, earns her living by operating a general store business and as a chusphachem dealer. Her husband, Jenito R., 45, works as a farmer and a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have three children, ages 15, 17, and 19 years old.

Maria Natividad joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maria Natividad has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9000, thereby uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 as additional capital for business, for her children's education and to continue to save up for future home repairs. Maria Natividad R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Melodina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Melodina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melodina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Melodina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Melodina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Salman's Group

texts.en:
Salman lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari with her husband and five daughters and one son. All of them are being educated and read in kindergarten and 2nd standard. A very caring and responsible mother and housewife, Salman arises early, mending clothes and cooking healthy meals.

Salman's husband is a sweetmeat producer and seller, and for the last 15 years has operated a shop in the market where he displays his items to customers. Having repaid her first loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan), Salman is now applying for a new loan to expand her husband’s business. The loan will enable him to buy more items such as milk, sugar, dry fruits and cooking oil for his shop. She is hopeful that her husband’s business will thus expand and earn him more income.

loans.use: Purchase items for sweetmeat selling business

loans.name: Hayne

texts.en:
Hayne A., a 50-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two businesses, rice retailing and charcoal sales, lives in Andres Bonifacio, Brgy. Poblacion, Bawayan City, Negros Oriental.

A member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008, she has improved her living conditions through her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF. By working hard in both of her enterprises, she is gradually making her family more economically stable and is now earning an average income of PHP 7,500.

Hayne is requesting PHP 14,000 for her children's education. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, her previous loan of PHP10,000 paid off well within its term, just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Hayne aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For her children's education

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Lorn S., 25 (pictured with her young daughter), and her husband, Mr. Broshun Nhoem, 30, have been married since 1998 and have two young daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Lorn has been selling fish for ten years, making her purchases from fisherman in the village and then selling them at Prek Phnao market. Her husband assists her in the business. She is asking for her first loan of $250 to add to her own money to purchase a motorbike to transport the fish to market.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a motorbike to transport fish to sell.

loans.name: Merceditha

texts.en:
Merceditha G., a married woman living in Sta. Catalina Municipality, Negros Oriental, earns her living by buying and selling dry goods and operating a photocopier business. Her husband, Edgardo G., 54, works as the owner of the photocopier business to earn for their family. They have six children ranging in age from 12 to 34 years old.

Merceditha joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Merceditha has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000 helped her earn a profit of PHP 200/ day, thereby uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to use for household expenses and to continue to save up for her children's future education. Merceditha G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

texts.en:
Mr. Koeun S. (pictured above), 37, and his wife, Mrs. Bo Klang, 32, have been married since 2003 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both still young. They live in a small village along National Road Number Four about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Koeun has been a construction worker for ten years, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for five years. Their house needs repairs, but he does not have the money and so is requesting his first loan for $500 for that purpose.

Chona has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Chona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Chona is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Chona from HSPFI. Mr. Kong B. and his wife, Mrs. Savoeun Soun (pictured together), live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, got married in 1979, and have seven children: three sons and four daughters.  Five of them are married and live outside the family home; one son is a gardener and another one stays at home. 

Kong and his wife are gardeners. He is asking for his first loan in the amount of 250 USD to purchase neighboring land to expand his property.

loans.use: To purchase neighboring land to expand his property

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma B., a married woman living in Prk. Gabe, Brgy. Malingin, Bago City, Negros Occidental, earns her living by operating both a general store and a standing crop (sugarcane) business. Her husband, Nolito B., 72, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children ranging in age from 33 to 47 years old.

Emma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,400, thereby uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy another pig for fattening and stocks for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of their sugarcane field. Emma B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B., 38, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Roberto B., a landscaper, they are blessed with four children. She has been managing her own landscaping business together with her husband for the past few years.

Evelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and paying her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the loans to expand and improve her landscaping business.

To ensure the continued success of her enterprise, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan to be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy additional materials and supplies needed for their landscaping projects.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additonal materials and supplies needed for their landscaping projects

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S. (pictured with her husband), age 41 years old, and her husband, Mr. Thea Sot, age 40, married in 1988 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Phally has been selling bananas since she was single. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for fifteen years. She is asking for her first loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase a motorbike to carry bananas to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to carry bananas to sell

loans.name: Phai

texts.en:
Mr. Phai U. (pictured with his wife), is 56 years old and his wife, Mrs. Kimheng Kong, is 50 years old. They live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1979, and have eight children: three sons and five daughters. Three of them are garment factory workers, one assists his father in their farming business, and four attend school.  

Phai has been a farmer for 17 years; he grows eggplant and melons on his farmland in the village. His wife has been selling vegetable for two years. Phai does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his farm and pay for plowing fees. 

Hence he is asking for a loan in the amount of 1,200 USD as additional working capital.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide and pay for plowing

The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Tranquilina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tranquilina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tranquilina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Kousar Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Kousar Perveen lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari, Pakistan. She owns a small house with two rooms there and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years.  She has given birth to six children: three boys and three girls. Her eldest son is a welder by profession. The other are enrolled in school and read in 2nd and 3rd standards. 

Her husband is a driver by profession and drives a rented rickshaw. He can’t work with the rented rickshaw for long hours and also has to pay rent which decreases his income to almost half. 

Kousar has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her husband. He will buy his own rickshaw that will bring him more income because he will no longer need to pay rent and will also be able to work without any time limitations.

loans.use: Purchase a rickshaw

loans.name: Sochea

texts.en:
Mr. Sochea L. (pictured with his wife), is 46 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sary Doung, is 35 years old. They have been married since 1992 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers and another one attends school. The family lives about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sochea has been driving a Tuk Tuk (motorcycle) taxi for three years. His wife has been a garment factory worker for two years. The couple is in the process of building new house, but they lack money to finish it. So, Sochea is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 in order to make the finishing touches.

loans.use: To finish his house building.

Mrs. Ron S. (pictured here), 31, and her husband, Mr. Chumsambath S., 41, live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1998 and just have one son who attends school.    

Ron has been selling roasted beef in front of her house for two years. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for fifteen years. She is requesting her first loan in the amount of US$ 500 to pay for house building.

Paquita S., from the village of Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte, is 58 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Paquita owns a business venture ofering motorcycle transport services. Engaged in her business for seven years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Paquita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Maushi

texts.en:
Maushi is a married woman with one child who goes to school. She has been operating her motorcycle business for the last two years, her potential customers being neighbors and passersby.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase new spare parts for her motorcycle. She faces the main challenge of competition as many people have ventured in the motorcycle business. Her main aim is to own a van in future.

Maushi decided to join Yehu because of their sustainable financial services to enable her to uplift her business. She owns a home with electricity and cites food and school fees as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To purchase new spare parts for her motorcycle

loans.name: Malumbo Group

texts.en:
Kurwa S., 44, is married with 3 children ages 20, 18 and 12, all of whom go to school. Kurwa also supports his brother in law who is 14 years old and goes to school.  He has had a Genge Duka (kiwahili fruits, vegetables, rice, sugar, wheat flour, etc) and a men's salon business since 1999.   He works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and he is able to make a monthly profit of about $645.

This will be  Kulwa’s first Motisha loan (a loan given to clients who pay their dues on time and in full) from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He wants to get a loan to increase stock in the Genge Duka. He hopes that when he makes a good profit and has enough savings, he will be able to pay school fees; he also dreams of building his own house.

Kulwa will share this loan with his loan group Malumbo, which totals 6 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Kulwa is the only man.

loans.use: increasing store inventory

loans.name: Shahida Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Shahida perveen lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari Pakistan with her family. Her family consists of four persons: her husband, two sons and herself as well.  

Her husband is a loader by profession. He uses a donkey cart to deliver items such as fruits & vegetables to designated places. He has been doing this work for over five years.  Shahida also operates an animal food selling business. She prepares animal food by receiving orders from her neighbors because her community people are involved in livestock businesses. She and her husband both use their income to meet the expenses of the family and to improve their financial situation. 

Shahida has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her husband. With the loan he will buy a new donkey cart because the old cart has become rough and rotted in different areas, causing its cargo to fall out. She is hopeful that the new donkey cart will help her husband do his work better and make better profits.

Note: she shows her cutter in this picture which helps her prepare animal food.

loans.use: buying a new donkey cart for hauling business

loans.name: Wito Group

texts.en:
Ummy K., age 40, is married with 3 children, aged 18, 15, and 9.   She has had a beauty salon and a grocery for 10 years now.   She works from 8am to 11pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $366.

This will be Ummy’s 2nd Motisha (motisha is to motivate good clients) loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to increase the stock on both businesses, equipment for the salon and more drinks for the grocery and has paid back the loan successfully.  She hopes for a loan to buy more beer, soda, spirits and water for the grocery and to buy more salon equipment. When Ummy makes her profits, she wants to pay school fees for her children and also household expenses. Her dreams is to start selling cosmetics.

Ummy will share this loan with her loan group Wito, which totals 11 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Ummy is second from right, in a blue dress in front row.

loans.use: buying more beer, spirits, and soda for the grocery; buying salon equipment

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is a father of four.  He does farming together with his wife and has two other employees.  He also runs a retail shop to get extra income.  Michael has been a farmer for ten years and he joined a group called Ikinu Star One in Faulu Kenya.  In this group, the members guarantee each other's loan.  He also saves his money on weekly basis with the group.  This has helped him to invest in his business.  He previously took out a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Faulu Kenya and successfully repaid it.  He has requested a loan of 60,000 KES to buy two dairy cows for more milk production.  He hopes to stabilize his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy two dairy cattle

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito M. Jr. is from the village of Langcataon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. He is 29 years old. Juanito is single. Juanito owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Juanito has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2007, Juanito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. He has successfully repaid his last loan from HSPFI, which was for 7,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Juanito is now requesting his fourth loan from HSPFI, for 10,000 PHP, which will be used to to expand the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. sells vegetables at a market for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new motorbike with a trailer attached to transport her vegetables to sell at the market. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna J. is from the village of Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Myrna is widowed and has 2 children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Myrna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sot

texts.en:
Sot O., 47, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. O. sells ice-creams for an income of USD 5 per day. His wife grows garlic to sell, earning an income of about USD 2.30 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

O. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike to transport ice creams to sell. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike to transport his ice-cream

loans.name: Niolie

texts.en:
Niolie V. is a 45-year old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: Videoke business, Computer games and running a general store. She lives in Prk. Tuburan, Brgy. Malingin, Bago City, Negros Occidental.  

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now eans an average income of PHP12,000. 

Niolie is borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can buy more inventory for her store. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Niolie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

texts.en:
Erlinda R. is a 60-year-old widow who supports her family by running a general store. She lives in Zone 1 Tabao, Valladolid, Negros Occidental with her seven school-aged children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 9,000.

Erlinda is borrowing Php 10,000 to use as additional working capital for her store. This will be her 18th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 22,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Erlinda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

This will be  Farida’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She wants to get a loan to buy more beers, sodas, water, spirits and increase her inventory for the retail shop. Farida's dream is to buy a pick-up so that she can transport her goods, both for retail and grocery items. She really wants to send her children to good standard schools. 

Farida will share this loan with her loan group Loyola, which totals 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture,  Farida  is in the centre in a black blouse with a yellow collar.

loans.use: To increase grocery and retail shop stock

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily S. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Mahida-eton, Brgy. Sampinit, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fish-vending business. Her husband, Edmundo S., who is 35 years old, works as a fisherman and also helps in his wife's business. They have two children, 8 and 9 years old. 

Emily joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family  With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emily has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000 — raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 4th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use to buy fishing nets so that she can continue to save for her future and for her children's education. Emily S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike for their child to commute to school. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.
