Her husband, Juvelin M., who is 35 years old, works as a fisherman and a carpenter to earn his living. He also helps with his wife's business activities. They have a 3-year-old child. 

Myra joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Myra has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000 - increasing the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her fifth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000. With the loan, she intends to purchase a pump boat so that she can continue to save for their future and for their child to complete his education. Myra M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 52-year-old farmer in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is married with three children and heads a family of three people who live with him in their own home. He is engaged in tea farming which is a popular cash crop in the Fort Portal area, as many people earn income from it. He has been a tea farmer for 15 years now. 

John says he was at first employed but later retired to fully engage in the tea growing business. He says labor and sometimes lack of good market in terms of prices are his biggest challenges. However with good markets to come, as the Government has promised farmers like John, he expects a good future in the business. He is to use the loan funds to buy fertilizer for the tea plantation so as to expand output.

loans.use: Buying fertilizer for his tea plantation

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes O. is a married woman who lives in the Kanggapas zone of Anahaw village in Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a sugarcane business. Her husband Guillermo, who is 45 years old, works as a truck driver to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 13 and 23 years old.

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari, Pakistan with her husband and four children. All of them are young and getting their education. Her husband is involved in the business of selling cosmetics while Sajida helps her husband by doing embroidery which she started by taking a loan through Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan).

Sajida has applied for the second time for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her husband’s cosmetics business. He will add more variety of cosmetic products to his shop such as nail polishes, creams, lipsticks, and face creams etc. She is hopeful that her husband’s income will be increased by investing money into the business, and her family will be able to enjoy the basic necessities of life. 

Note: The cutter in this photo belongs to Sugran, a member of Sajida's group. She uses it to prepare food for her buffalo.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics for reselling

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard G. N. is forty-seven years old, married to a farmer, and they have three children aged between nineteen years and sixteen years old. His business is located at a busy residential area called Kiganjo in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

Bernard has been providing boda boda (motorcycle) transport to the local people. He has been doing this business for one year. He has no employees yet. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is during the rainy seasons when the roads become impassable. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy a motorcycle to expand his business. He hopes to be a buy a plot of land and build rental houses in future. He also hopes to give his children quality education. He describes himself as humble, hard-working, and ambitious.

loans.use: Motorcycle

S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to raise pigs. loans.use: buy a motorbike to use to commute to work

loans.name: Rogelio

To make a living, Rogelio owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Rogelio has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rogelio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rogelio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita G. is a 44-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: fish vending and hog fattening businesses. She lives in the Kanggapas zone of barangay Anahaw, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her fish vending and hog fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now eans an average income of PHP 7,500 per month. 

Angelita is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she could a bigger volume of fish to sell. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Angelita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the  Dungganon way. 

The accompanying picture was taken after Angelita sold all her stocks of fish for the day.

loans.name: Vennicah

texts.en:
Vennicah K. O. is twenty eight years old, married, and has two children aged eight years old and three years.

Vennicah’s business is located at Juja, a busy market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. She has been selling vegetables such as tomatoes, kale, cabbages, carrots and other vegetables for the last two years to the local people.

Vennicah says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is fluctuating market prices, hence selling her produce at low prices. Changes in weather patterns also affects the production and harvest of these vegetables, hence affecting the prices. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Vennicah is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more vegetables to expand her business. She hopes to grow her business and be able to supply in larger quantities to the local people. She describes herself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to expand her business

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda V. is a married woman who lives in zone 2, barangay Nabulao, Sipalay, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: buying and selling rice, being an Avon dealer and running a pig fattening business. Her husband Edwin V., who is 47 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have two children, who are 20 and 23 years old. 

Imelda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Imelda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 11,080 - uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,500, which she intends to use to buy rice and other feeds so that she can continue saving for their future and expand the business. Imelda V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem C., 69, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean temples. She and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 5 each per day to help cover the family expenses.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase fertilizers and a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C. is the old woman in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and a motorbike

loans.name: Jungie

texts.en:
Jungie J. is from the village of Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. He is 30 years old and is single. Jungie owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Jungie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jungie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his fourth from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Mi

texts.en:
Mi P., 30, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean Temples.

P. produces traditional baskets to sell for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of about USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to use for commuting

loans.name: Jay Ven

texts.en:
Jay Ven G. is from Camen Annex, Ozamiz City. He is 25 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Jay Ven owns and operates a business operating motorcycle transportation services. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Jay Ven joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jay Ven is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be his second from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his existing vehicle to provide better service

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
Gertrudes P., 29, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Ronnie P., a vendor, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling balut (cooked fertilized duck egg, a native delicacy) during the evenings while selling candy and pocketbooks during the day for the past few years.

Gertrudes has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative. She was consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, by buying additional products to be incorporated into her current inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional products to be incorporated into her current inventory

loans.name: Lux

texts.en:
Lux K., 23, is married and resides with her husband and young child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. K. is employed at a golf club for an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband is an equipment operator at the gold club, earning an income of about USD 3.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

K. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase piglets to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Vergencita

texts.en:
Vergencita T. is from the village of New Compostela, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Vergencita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Vergencita owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community through peddling. Vergencita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vergencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Vergencita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Vergencita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Antoneta

texts.en:
Antoneta T is currently in the business of selling maize, millet, sorghum, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more cereals to sell.  Antoneta is 41 years old and is widowed.   She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more cereals to sell

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda F. is a 55 year old married woman who supports her family by raising livestock and engaging in buying and selling of rice grains. She lives in Prk Bamandayan, Barangay Buenavista, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental with her 53 year old husband, Inocenioa, a carpenter, and their 7 children who are between 16 and 37 years old. Three of their children already have their own families. The other 3 are already working and help their parents. They still have one child currently going school.

Hilda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1995 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her livestock raising and buying and selling of rice grains business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Hilda is now borrowing PHP 23,000 so that she can add additional working capital to her business re-open her general store. This will be her 17th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Hilda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital and re-opening of her general store business.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth S. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 31 years old. Janeth is married to Richard and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Janeth owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Janeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Janeth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the second loan taken out by Janeth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Evgeniy

texts.en:
Evgeniy is married. He and his wife Anzhella have two children. Evgeniy sells sport shoes at one of the markets in Melitopol town. He started this business 13 years ago. Today he owns two business locations and offers a large assortment of sport shoes. He has many repeat customers that can buy inventory with a discount. Evgeniy loves wearing sport shoes himself and enjoys his work. 

Evgeniy has used business loans before and found them very helpful for his business development. Evgeniy would like to borrow 20,000 UAH to increase the assortment of summer sport shoes. He hopes to receive additional income and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to increase the assortment

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Shamim Akhtar lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband works in the fields while her son runs a grocery shop at the market. He started the grocery shop ten years ago to financially support his family, leaving his education. He spent his time growing his business. His family appreciates his struggle and caring attitude towards them.  

These days, his shop needs renovation and more stock to fulfill the needs of the clients. Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her son. With the loan amount he will buy the necessary items such as rice, lentils, and cooking oil, and renovate his grocery shop.   

Shamim is applying for a loan for the first time and is hopeful that her son’s income will increase and her family will be able to enjoy a better standard of living. 

Note: In this photo, Fatima, a group member of Shamim's, is showing off her washing machine which she bought with the profit from the first loan which she received from Asasah.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for her son's grocery shop

loans.name: Jess

texts.en:
Jess E. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 40 years old. Jess is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jess owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

In December 2009, Jess joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jess has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jess is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the second loan taken out by Jess from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson G. M. is thirty years old, married, and has two sons aged nine years old and four years old. His business is located in Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. He has been selling fruit such as bananas, water melon, oranges, apples, mangoes, avocados, paw paws and pineapples for the last three years to the local people. He also supplies fruits to other fruit vendors in the area. 

Benson says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are other people in the area doing the same business as his and so customers are not very loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more fruits to expand his business. He hopes to expand his business to wholesale, open up a food processing plant and become the manager. He describes himself as charismatic, hard-working and focused.

loans.use: buying more fruit for resale

loans.name: Ailen

texts.en:
Ailen A. is a 33-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  a General Store and Farming. She lives in Prk. Maligaya, Barangay Malingin, Bago City, Negros Occidental.  

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of PHP7,000. Ailen is now borrowing PHP 28,000 so that she can buy more fertilizer and inventory for the general store.  

This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Ailen aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina O. is from the village of Galas, Dipolog City. She is 32 years old. Paulina is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Paulina owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Paulina is just starting this business.

In 2009, Paulina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Paulina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Paulina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as start up capital for fresh and dried fish vending. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Paulina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as start up capital for fresh and dried fish vending.

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is married, with three children all attending school. She has been operating her food stall  for the last five years as a retail business, neighbors  being her potential customers. Previously she was running a shop from home hence contributing to her other source of livelihood to the family. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to renovate her food stall. Her major challenge in the business is theft.

She decided to work with Yehu so as to acquire loans and modify her business. Medina hopes to have a hotel and a wholesale shop someday. She owns a home with electricity but no piped water, citing food as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To  renovate her food stall

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables such as okra, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  Mary is 38 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Thirty-six-year-old Marilyn N. is from the town of Sta. Josefa, where she is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Marilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new one for 7000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Marilyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her enterprise and pay her children's tuition fees.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia M. is a widow who lives in Gilside, Barangay Nabulao, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  a General Store and Pig fattening. 

Letecia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Letecia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 11,300 - uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 22nd cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy more inventory for her general store business. This will allow her to continue to save up for their future and for the expansion of their business. Letecia M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Nasiridin

texts.ru: Пармонкулов Насиридин проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 55 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Дети живут и работают в России. Сам Насиридин имеет средне - специальное образование. По специальности проработал более 10 лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. Сажает фрукты и овощи для перепродажи их на рынке. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Nasiridin P. lives in the area of Shahrituz. 55 years of age. Married, with 7 children. His children work and live in Russia. Nasiridin himself has a postsecondary trade school diploma. He worked over ten years in his trade. Now he is a farmer. He grows fruits and vegetables in order to sell them at the market. He has been in this business for 15 years already. He is taking out a loan in order to buy mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Chhorng

texts.en:
Chhorng C., 64, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. C. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 5 each per day to help cover the family expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD 1100 to purchase fertilizers and a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C. appears in the photograph with her husband and daughter.

loans.use: buy fertilizers and a motorbike

loans.name: Daisy's Group

texts.en:
Daisy D. is from the village of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Daisy is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Daisy is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Daisy owns & operates a "Nipa" (native roof making) business, selling "nipa" in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Daisy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Daisy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 14500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Daisy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her standard of living. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for "nipa" (native roof making).

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita D. is a married woman who lives in Prk. 4, Brgy. Basak, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sugarcane plantation, a corn plantation and charcoal selling. Her husband Pablito, who is 58 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 12 children who are 11 to 35 years old. Anita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Anita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 20,000. She intends to use it to buy and sell charcoal so that she can continue to save up for their future and to send their children to school and expand her business. Anita D. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy and sell charcoal

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari in Pakistan with her husband and four children. Vehari is near Multan, a city of shrines. One of Rani's sons is a rickshaw driver and another is a security guard. Her husband is a retired government official and Rani does embroidery to share the financial burden of her family. Her children couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints so they had to work. 

Rani has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son who wants to buy his own rickshaw. A new rickshaw will not only help him avoid paying the cost of vehicle rent but he will also able to do his work more efficiently. 

Rani hopes that a new rickshaw will bring in more income for her family and she will be able to send her younger ones, who still couldn’t start their education, to school.

loans.use: Purchase a rickshaw for her son

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand was born in 1970 and is married, without children. Ferdinand is a businessman; he does not have another member in his family who works, so he works hard in order to develop his business as well as the family. Ferdinand declares that his business is well-known as well as organized; he employs two people as helpers in his business. This is his fourth year of successful operation in business. The hours of his business are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Ferdinand is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing more foodstuffs which will allow him to attract more customers and earn more profit which will help him to sort out his family problems and business problems

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: William Juma

texts.en:
William has been extracting stones for eight years now.  He is 28 years old, married to Alice Akinyi, and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He is planning to buy new tools for his trade as the ones he has are worn out.  

William hopes to grow his business and extract more stones in future.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his stone extraction trade

loans.name: Pet

texts.en:
Pet S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean temples. S. sells Chinese noodles and cakes for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is from the town of Poblacion, Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 34 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo E., 51 years old, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is married and has 5 school-aged children. Reynaldo owns and operates a farming business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for more than 20 years.

Reynaldo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. He is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Reynaldo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Remy

texts.en:
Remy B. is a 65-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures buying and selling rice. She lives in Prk 1, Brgy. Tuyom, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts working hard in her rice businesses. She is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of PHP10,000. 

Remy is borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can use it to purchase rice, as additional capital and for fertilizer.  This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP27,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Remy aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Susan is 45 years old and married to a policeman. She has 4 children and they all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, Susan hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mikhailo

texts.en:
Mikhailo is married. He lives in Korolyovo and sells various items: bicycle parts, video games, TV antennas, cameras, etc. His vending kiosk is located right in the center of the market, which makes it a good attraction for potential customers. Mikhailo has been in this trade for six years. Currently, he has 30,000 UAH in his inventory. His gross income amounts to 10,000 UAH a month, and his monthly net profit doesn’t exceed 4,000 UAH.

Mikhailo is seeking a loan of 11,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. Mikhailo is a goal-oriented businessman who’d like to continue growing his enterprise by opening new sales locations.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine was born in 1973 and is married with five children who are aged between 2 and 12. No one in her family works, only Josephine herself, and this situation requires her to work hard so that she provides her children with all their needs.

Josephine owns a small business selling charcoal and has an experience of sixteen years in her business. The hours of her business are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Sunday.

Now, Josephine is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more sacks of charcoal. This purchasing of more sacks will allow her to satisfy her customers which will make her more efficient and effective and more successful.

loans.use: To expand her business through purchasing more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. She is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase construction materials to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits from the business to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to expand her husband's business.

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en: Shirly M. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 23 years old, is married, and has a 4-year-old child. Shirly has been involved in farming for nine years now. She cultivates her land for rice crops and sells her harvest at their local market. She says that she is really thankful for the farm because it provides for her family's daily needs. She also saves for her child's future. Shirly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Shirly is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seed and fertilzer. This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seed and fertilzer

loans.name: Lung

texts.en:
Lung M., 56, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. M. appears in the photograph with her husband.

M. sells snacks at a primary school for an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 5 per day.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase cosmetics products. By doing so, M. is able to help one of her daughter to expand her business of selling cosmetics. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics products for her daughter to sell

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 36 years old and is married with four children. She works hard for the purpose of growing her business and taking care of her family.

Francoise has chosen this general store business in her place of residence that you see in the photo because it is profitable. Her business is well organized and she employs three people as helpers so that her business runs smoothly. The hours of her business are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening except on Sunday.

Francoise is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more products for her shop. Once her vision is reached, she will be able to attract more customers which will allow her to earn more profits.

loans.use: To expand her business through purchasing more products

loans.name: Sarn

texts.en:
Sarn S., 51, is widowed and lives with her three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. sells Cambodian noodles for an income of USD 6 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to use to commute to work.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for one of her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Paska

texts.en: Paska D. is currently in the business of selling clothes and shoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more shoes to sell. Paska is 41 years old and is married to a clinical officer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more shoes to sell

loans.name: Erkinjon

texts.ru: Шералиев Эркинжон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 30 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование средне. Более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. Арендует земельный участок, где сажает овощи и фрукты. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Erkinjon S. lives in the area of Shahrituz. 30 years of age. Married, with two children. He has finished secondary school. He has been doing farm work for over six years. He rents a land plot where he grows vegetables and fruits. He is taking out a loan in order to buy mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan P., 35, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

P. buys rice for resale and earns an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a civil servant at the commune hall, earning an income of about USD 4 per day.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more rice to add to her stock and also to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more rice to add to her stock and to repair her house

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie M. is a married woman who lives in Purok Talisay, Brgy. Enclaro Vista Aligre, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  food vending and nipa (palm leaves that are woven together and used as roofing material). Her husband, Leopoldo, who is 56 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are 10 to  24 years old. 

Rosie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000 — increasing the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to lease nipa so that she could continue to save up for their future.  Rosie M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong C., 41, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

C. sells fish for an income of USD 9.80 per day. Her husband is a skillful fisherman. C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase fishing equipment to enable her husband to catch more fish to sell.

In the future, C. would like to use any additional profit to help her children’s study. This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment for her husband's fishing business

loans.name: Ganhavh

texts.en:
Ganhavh E. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his sons, ages 15 and 12, attend a local secondary school.

Ganhavh has been operating a wooden-products business in his town since 2000, especially a horse-head fiddle-making business, and has found success in his trade. He designs and produces many different styles and sizes of the musical instrument that he sells throughout his community including sales at Nomin Department Store, Flower Trade Center, and Souvenir House. His wife is in charge of the production sales. With the business profit, the family purchased a house.

For the future, Ganhavh says, "My main business goal is to continue to produce quality products and to enlarge my business by completing a newly-built workplace for my customers. I am thinking of hiring four skilled employees."

Ganhavh is very hardworking and modest person and is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials for his new workplace building. Ganhavh is to the right of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for his new workplace

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with three children and all her children go to school. She also take care of a young brother. She lives in and rents and a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, rent and food.

Betty sells African attire and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She sells door–to-door and so doesn’t have a permanent business premises. She has been in this business for four-and-a-half years, working six days a week.

Betty joined MCDT because of the low interest rate charged. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of African fabric (bitenge). Formerly she was buying this from Arua but shifted to the Democratic Republic of Congo. She uses public transport to and from buying her goods. 

Betty’s business challenges include transportation, defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her movements. She is aspiring to selling wholesale only and also wants to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of African fabric

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. She is a tailor and earns an income of USD 2.7 per day. Her husband is a motorbike repairman, and he sprays color to old motorbikes, earning an income of USD 15 per day. 

Sophea is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase motorbike paints in order to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to help pay for her children’s studies.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy motorcycle paints

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita T. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 46 years old. Teresita is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha B. is currently in the business of selling bread, tomatoes and groundnut phase (similar to peanut butter) and is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil and tomatoes to sell. Asha is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by its scale and the diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock cooking oil and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Aleciana

texts.en:
Aleciana A. is a married woman who lives in Sto. Niño, Brgy. San Pedro, Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  a general store, pump boat and pedicab.  Her husband, Nelson, who is 39 years old, works as a pedicab driver to earn his living.  They have two children who are 9 and 10 years old. 

Aleciana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Aleciana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 13,500 — increasing the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy stocks for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her children's education. Aleciana A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her store

loans.name: Hail

texts.en:
Mrs. R. is a young woman whose husband appears on the photo here. She has been providing a laundry service for people in the village and normally earns approximately $4 per day to cover the financial needs of her family. 

R. depends on the revenue from her husband’s job. He buys cars and paints them at his home before selling them to other people to gain income.

The couple was married and blessed to two small kids, who are not enrolled in school. The family living situation is not comfortable, because their house is very old and needs repairs. R. is applying for a loan to hire a repairman to mend her old house.

loans.use: To hire a repairman to mend her old house.

loans.name: Charles  Odhiambo

texts.en:
Charles has been in the quarry business, extracting and selling stone blocks, for 15 years. He is 38 years old and married to Milka Akinyi, with whom he has five children.  

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy another plot from which to extract stones.

In the future, Charles plans to start livestock farming, which he will run simultaneously with the quarry.

loans.use: To buy another land plot from which to extract stones

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Esperance R. est une commerçante âgée de 47ans qui habite la Commune de Cibitoke en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de l’eau minérale et de la Bière industrielle alcoolisée au quartier Cibitoke à Bujumbura. C’est un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 6ans alors qu’elle prestait comme Agent de sante communautaire. Elle detententrice du Diplôme A3 comme ménagère. Son époux, Bernard Sinzobakwira, est un menuisier. Elle est maintenant  au 3e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 5 enfants dont 3 garçons et 2 filles et 4 d’entre eux ont déjà terminé leurs études. Elle prend aussi en charge 3 enfants de  sa famille proche. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour diversifier son business avec les produits vivriers comme le haricot, le riz qu’elle compte vendre en plus des boissons  aux clients. Elle espère ainsi que cela lui permettra d’acquérir une plus grande capacité de générer du bénéfice et faire ses épargnes pour s’acheter sa propre maison. Elle reconnaît qu’elle  a dû commencer son business grâce au capital donné par son mari.

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Confiance ».
texts.en:
Esperance R. is a 47-year-old merchant living in the Citiboke borough of the Bujumbura mayorship, where she retails sparkling water and commercial beer. She has been performing this activity for the past six years, prior to which she was a community health agent. She obtained an homemaker diploma, at the A3 level. Her husband Bernard Sinzobakwira is a carpenter. She is now in her third group loan cycle with Turame. She is the mother of five children - three boys and two girls – of whom four have already finished school. She also takes care of three children of close relatives. She is requesting the Kiva loan to diversify her business with food products such as beans and rice, which she intends to sell to her customers, in addition to beverages. She hopes that this will enable her to acquire a greater capacity to generate revenue and save money to build her own home. She recognises that she started her business thanks to funds provided by her husband. She is one of the members of the “Confiance” community group (which means “Trust”).

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: diversify her business with food products such as beans and rice, which she intends to sell to her customers, in addition to beverages.

loans.name: Zulaikhan's Group

texts.en:
Zulaikhan lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari with her family. Her husband works in a factory while Zulaikhan runs a grocery shop out of her home. Presently, she is not running it because she has almost finished off her stock by selling it. She has changed her business to sewing. Now she runs a domestic sewing business. This business doesn’t give her the expected amount. That’s why she has decided to start the grocery business again. She mentioned that there is potential in the grocery business because her shop was the only one in her area. Zulaikhan has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest capital into buying groceries for her grocery shop. She is certain that she can increase her family's income by making positive changes to her shop.

Note: Zulaikhan is showing her sewing work in this photo.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to start a grocery shop again

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma T. is from the village of Omonay, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 48 years old. Emma is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase pesticides and fertilizers. Emma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to pay services extended by laborers plowing her corn field. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Joel Ntakaine

texts.en:
Joel has been a wheat farmer for 10 years now. He is 32 years old and married to Elizah Kaamamia. They have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan of Kshs 20,000 well and on time.  He plans to use cash from this loan to buy pesticides and fertiliser for his wheat crops.

In the future, Joel hopes he will be able to buy his own tractor and combine harvester.

loans.use: To buy fertiliser and pesticides for his wheat crop

loans.name: Sambath's Group

texts.en:
C. Sambath, P. Leab, S. Phally and A. Sreileak have taken out a loA. as part of AMK’s loA. workout program. Each client has A. outstanding loA. with AMK that they are unable to repay. C. Sambath obtained a loA. to buy more fruit to re-sell but she made a loss and she was not able to repay the loA.. She quit her business and went on to cut a grass for a living instead. Her salary allows her to support her four children, but not to repay her loA. or improve her livelihood.

As part of AMK’s workout program, each client is trained to produce a product. The four members of C. Sambath’s group have been trained to produce clutch purses. They have been given a loA. to purchase sewing machines, while AMK provides them with materials to produce the goods. Ahkun.org will purchase the goods from the clients and sell them on their website. Profits from the sale will go to the group to help them pay off their outstanding loans, and the loans of their fellow villagers who are in the same difficult position. 

C. Sambath, P. Leab and S. Phally have had previous loans of theirs funded on Kiva.org:

http://www.kiva.org/lend/51659
http://www.kiva.org/lend/51660
http://www.kiva.org/lend/58350

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines.

loans.name: Erlany

texts.en:
Erlany C. is from the village of Old Damulog, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Erlany is single. To make a living, Erlany owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Erlany has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlany joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlany has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Erlany is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Erlany from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Koileken Ole

texts.en:
Koileken is 37 years old and married to Lucy K., with whom he has one child. He has been in wheat farming since 1998 and he sells all his produce to the Cereals Board, a government body.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to prepare his land and buy seedlings for wheat and barley planting.

In the near future, Koileken plans to buy his own farm equipment, which will save him the cash he spends on renting this equipment, and also will make his farming more convenient, as he will have the equipment to himself.

loans.use: To prepare his land to plant wheat and barley

loans.name: Chancel Yannick

texts.fr:
une homme commercant de 26 ans, ayant fait des etudes universitaires ,a la fin de ses etudes ne trouvant pas debouches sur le marche du travail va se lancer dans la vente des habits hommes de qualite 
il s'approvissionne dans les grandes boutiques de la place, les grossistes qui viennent de la chine et la France.Avec ce pret il pense acheter des habits d'hommes comme pantalons en velours , des pantalons en Jeans, chemises jeans et autres articles apprecies par les jeunes hommes
En moyenne il a une recette journaliere de 30000frs a 60000fr par jour.Etant economiste de formation  il use de beaucoup de strategies pour faire accroitre son activite comme l'epargne , rigueur dans sa gestion.
A la longue il veut avoir une manufacture pour aider a freiner le chomage
texts.en:
This man is a 26-year-old merchant who, having completed university-level studies, found no opportunities in the employment market and started a business selling quality men’s clothing. He gets his supplies from major local wholesalers who import from France or China. With this loan, he plans to buy men's clothing such as corduroy pants, jeans, jean shirts and other items that are currently in style for younger men. His daily income varies between 30,000 and 60,000 francs. Having been trained as an economist, he makes use of various strategies to grow his business, and eventually intends to own a factory and help curb unemployment.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de pantalons en jeans ,en  velours et chemise hommes

loans.name: Saut

texts.en: Mrs. Saut S. I has been spending her life cultivating rice and vegetable crops. It is the main activity that she has ever done with great success.
